DOC.HEAD: Campbell Soup Board Completes Search for New Executive
DOC.TEXT: Campbell Soup Co. said Friday it has completed its search for a new chief executive officer but will not disclose its choice until next week. Campbell Chairman Robert J. Vlasic said the board of directors' first choice has accepted an offer to succeed R. Gordon McGovern, who retired in November as president and chief executive officer of the food-products company. The announcement comes amid growing dissent among members of Campbell's founding family, who control about 59 percent of the company's 129.6 million outstanding common shares. Three family members announced Thursday they would sell their 17 percent stake and urge a sale of the entire company. The board is to hold final deliberations on the selection next week, but company officials said the talks are a formality. ``We have interviewed many candidates and are confident that we have the best qualified person for the job,'' Vlasic said in a statement. Campbell spokesman James H. Moran said he did not know if the announcement was prompted by a growing rift in the Dorrance family and increased speculation the company would be put up for sale. At the company's annual shareholders meeting in November, Vlasic said a successor to McGovern would be named early next year. Moran said he did not know whom the board picked and could provide no information about the search. The board of directors formed a management succession committee about a year ago in anticipation of McGovern's retirement. McGovern, 63, became president and CEO in 1980. Executive vice-presidents Herbert M. Baum and Edwin L. Harper were named to oversee the company's day-to-day operations on an interim basis. Both were considered candidates to succeed McGovern. Campbell sells about 5 billion cans of soup a year. It also owns Pepperidge Farm, Vlasic Foods, Mrs. Paul's Kitchens, Godiva Chocolatier and Casera Foods.
